results.question: How are debts which are known to be uncollectable written off?
gold_answer: by reducing the carrying amount directly
results.markdown_table_response: Trade receivables are written off at amortised cost.
results.csv_string_response: Depending on the amount of debt, the Group’s ability to recover on trade receivables is evaluated using the effective interest method. The effective interest method is then applied to the trade receivable amount and the effective interest rate used to determine the amount of the trade receivable’s impairment allowance. The amount of the trade receivable’s impairment allowance is then compared with the amount of the trade receivable’s carrying amount. If the Group’s effective interest rate is greater than the amount of the trade receivable’s impairment allowance, the amount written off is reduced by the amount of the trade receivable’s impairment allowance. If the Group’s effective interest rate is less than the amount of the trade receivable’s impairment allowance, the amount written off is increased by the amount of the trade receivable’s impairment allowance.
results.json_rows_response:
The Group is able to write-off uncollectable trade receivables as follows:
(a) The amount is written off when the trade receivables are completely written off by reducing the carrying amount of the receivables from the amount which is written off.
(b) The amount is written off when the trade receivables are partially written off by reducing the carrying amount from the amount which is written off.
